Chryseobacterium metallicongregator is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Chryseobacterium, within the phylum Bacteroidetes. This species was first isolated from a copper mine in Japan.

Chryseobacterium metallicongregator is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, aerobic bacterium. It is rod-shaped and displays a characteristic yellowish pigmentation. This species is known for its ability to aggregate and form biofilms, particularly in the presence of heavy metals, such as copper.

The genome of Chryseobacterium metallicongregator has been sequenced, revealing insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to metal-rich environments. It is believed to possess mechanisms for tolerating and potentially accumulating heavy metals, which may contribute to its unique metal-aggregating behavior.

Chryseobacterium metallicongregator has been studied for its potential applications in bioremediation and metal recovery processes, as its metal-binding properties could be exploited for the removal of heavy metals from contaminated environments or the extraction of valuable metals from industrial waste streams.
